title: Tuesday, 12th February 2019
bodyHTML:
11:10 am

Following our latest assessment of the impact of the ESMA regulatory measures, FY19 revenue is expected to be lower than current market expectations. This, combined with our intention to maintain our marketing spend, is likely to result in 2019 profit being materially lower than current market expectations.

Or from $284 year on year in Q4, which was the crypto bubble and I customer acquisition was shooting very stupid fish in a very shallow barrel.

wayneJ And how much of the acquisition cost is spent with parties with links with current or previous management (not a trick question - I genuinely don't know)
1st Lt. Fletcher Christian Morning folks.
11:18 am
BE11:18am

Which brings us onto part two. It's not the leverage limitations that are stopping punters gambling. It's that they're stopping punters losing.

BE11:18am

Here's Peel Hunt.

BE11:19am

Whilst the year has started well, with new and active customer numbers and trading volumes currently above the levels seen at the end of 2018, Plus500 expects FY19 revenue to be lower than current market expectations and, in combination with its intention to maintain marketing spend, this is likely to result in the 2019 profit being materially lower. The reason for the warning is that Plus500 considers its revenue run-rate to be currently around $100m, having disclosed that revenue from client losses in Q4 was $56m and was achieved primarily given the bearish – but volatile – market, where clients are generally long. This has never been disclosed and to some extent makes more visible the inherent uncertainty in forecasting.

11:19 am
BE11:19am

Currently our FY19 PBT/EPS of $344.5m/¢239 are in line with consensus of $344.8m/¢233 and we expect both us and consensus to move FY19 forecasts down by between 20-25%.

BE11:19am

Valuation and recommendation. It has always been clear that the introduction of the new leverage rules was likely to cause a degree of market dislocation. The real surprise is that FY19 revenue will be significantly lower than we forecast given the revenue coming from client losses. Over time Plus500 is a beneficiary of such P&L because clients tend to lose, but this is a different quality of earnings and highlights the lack of visibility in earnings forecasts. We place our target price and recommendation under review.

BE11:20am

Which was always one of the central criticisms of Plus as an investment case: it takes punters, rinses them then spits them out again.

red thats the business plan
wayneJ Also how are betting companies focussed on grey markets like China regulated - just out of interest
11:20 am
BE11:20am

We never really had much clarity on how much the model relied on parting clients from their cash. And now we do.

red but much likes a lot of propaganda on the internet, it does seem to go away. a bit like the lottery
Bonnemort It must have been nice when companies made things and added value rather than finding better ways to extract money from the foolish
BE11:21am

The buyers here remain buyers, needless to say.

1st Lt. Fletcher Christian Plus500 = fanboy stock = stay well clear.
BE11:21am

Such as Berenberg.

11:21 am
BE11:21am

FY 2018 was a great year for
Plus500. It began with an exceptionally strong first quarter that benefited
from heightened levels of cryptocurrency trading (19% of FY 2018 revenue)
and ended with very high levels of market volatility. Revenue for the full
year was $720m (+65% yoy, Berenberg: $718m) and EBITDA was $506m
(+95% yoy, Berenberg: $498m). The company generated $400m of free cash
flow and declared a final dividend of 61.9c. However, management expects
both revenue and EBITDA for FY 2019 to be materially below current
market forecasts. This follows its latest assessment of the impact of the
European Securities and Markets Authority (ESMA) restrictions, combined
with a rise in marketing spend as the group continues to target highervalue
clients. Although this is disappointing in the short term, Plus500 has
an attractive business model (high margin, cash generative and capital
light), its revenues are positively correlated with financial market volatility,
and the regulatory impact has now been quantified, which removes the
major uncertainty facing the stock. We therefore retain our Buy
recommendation.

red BE. there has always been that clarity ;)
Lemmy Isn't that the MO of all the spread betters, with leverage punters are "picking pennies up in front of a steamroller" ?
hedgehog dwf IPO anyone?
red i think they may squeeze to 1330 but as said before imo they are a sell on blips rather than a buy on dips. need to be derated to under 10 quid imo.
Phil Half of their revenue comes from client losses? Sheesh.
Flaneur So Bryce - journalists as civil servants? FTAV as a public service?
BE11:22am

And Liberum.

BE11:22am

Elevated volatility is good for trading platforms, but market falls in Q4 caused significant client losses ("P&L gain”), rather than higher spread revenue. The company is choosing to subtract this gain from Q4 revenues and to base 2019 guidance on the organic growth which they have always achieved. We believe this guidance is cautious, since ARPU mix is positive, the EPC programme continues to raise ARPU, reactivations are up, churn has fallen dramatically, and marketing spend is being maintained at a high level to continue momentum for the business. Our new number puts the company on 11.7x 2019 and 9.2x 2020. The high professional revenues, richer mix of customers and lower churn will lead to a higher rating over time, but in the short term we set our price target at 10x 2020 or 1760p. BUY.

Cracklenpop It's a scandal that Gordon Banks and most of the other England World Cup winning team were never knighted. (Nobby Stiles also won the European Cup with United). Yet Mick Jagger and various Sir Bufton Tuftons get gongs. Embarrassing.
11:23 am
BE11:23am

Priced to 2020 post a profit warning. Yep, sure, why not.

red 77% revs from mobile. this tells u all u need to know about who is trading and their ability to avoid losing money.
BE11:24am

On the flipside, Canaccord's Justin Bates has been a seller and won't be changing today.

BE11:24am

Key takeaways from the statement:
• The company notes a total P&L gain of in FY18 of $172m (FY17: $103m loss). This comes as something of a surprise to us. This admission of the extent of client losses/profits will be seen as introducing unexpected volatility to earnings and just serve to reinforce the point that this should be a single digit PE business.
• Number of new active customers recruited in Q4'18 was 19,405, which is lower than the 20,684 reported for Q3. This is despite the significantly elevated volatility during the quarter. In light of this result, our below consensus forecast for 125k new active customers in each of FY19 and FY20 looks unachievable.
• Progress on elective professional client conversions appears slow. At the end of FY18, 7,229 customers were approved as EPCs, just 2% of the 2018 active customer base.
• Customer deposits were down by 34% y/y at the end of December, which provides further evidence that FY19 is set to be a very tough period.

FJ Profiting from gambling addiction. Not interested.
11:24 am
BE11:24am

We will revisit our forecasts post today's statement, which in light
of the outlook statement, poor new active customer recruitment and average user cost of acquisition which was 424% higher y/y in Q4'18 (versus our current forecasts for declining AUAC), will need to be pared back. Our current CY19 and CY20 forecasts are already 10% and 26% below consensus. The stock trades on our current estimates at 10.2x CY19 EPS, rising to 12.4x but with EPS clearly going backwards as confirmed in today's statement, and the DPS yield being 5.9% falling to 4.8% in CY20, we do not regard the yield as a support. Reiterate conviction SELL.

Citi can summarise so I don't have to.

BE11:33am

Group revenue grew +5% constant currency YoY at €3,705m (Citi €3,524m). Q1 underlying EBITA loss of –€84m, however excluding a €29m
currency hedge gain would leave adj EBITA loss of –€113m (Citi –€91m). The variance is driven by Markets & Airlines with Hotels and Cruise EBITA both ahead of exp. Net Debt is 13% higher than we expected at €1,832m (Citi €1,623m), due to slightly higher capex (phasing effect) and working capital outflow from increased hotel capacity last summer.

BE11:33am

We expect little change to consensus, given recently re-stated
management guidance and Q1 representing the seasonally low period of the year. Management note continued strong demand for Cruises, with load factor and yield performance in line with their expectations.

We also see potential for further airline consolidation medium term and delivery of €300m cost/efficiency improvements.

The Markets & Airlines (Tour Op) decline and quantum of net debt may capture the headlines this morning. Markets & Airlines Q1 EBITA declined €81m y/y. [...] the issues are the knock-on impact of the summer 2018 heat wave on bookings, overcapacity in Spain from the demand shift to the Eastern Med, pressure on yields, continued GBPweakness and strong comps intheNordics. Our estimates are unchanged from the guidance cut on 6 Feb: flat constant currency EBITA growth from ‘at least 10%’. Net debt has increased significantly y/yfrom €874m to €1,832mbut reflects more normal cash flows,i.e. not benefitting from disposals. Key movements include the expected delayed capex from Q4 FY18 which fell inQ1 FY19 (+€126m y/y) and higher working capital outflow for the payment of hotel creditors due mainly to increased capacity in summer 2018 intheCentral Region(+€223m). We expect a cautious sentimenttohangoverthe sector in the near term

BE11:36am

The shares trade on 8.7x cal19E P/E, 5.5x EV/EBITDA, 1.9% FCF yield, 6.7% dividend yield.The valuation appearsextremely cheap and perhaps presentsan attractive entry point for long-term investors. In the short term we expect sentiment to remain depressed andforconsumer concerns to present more downside than upside risk to estimates. We expect the debate to focus onthe sustainabilityof such a high dividendgoing forward. Importantly, we view 10% constant currency growth in 2020 and beyond as challenging. We assume 6-7% growth

BE11:42am

Debenhams is stuck between ‘a rock and a hard place’: negotiating a new longer-term finance facility (the current one expires next year) looks to be an impossible task while the business remains weighed down by legacy leases. A CVA would allow the business to rebase its occupancy costs to the economic reality of current footfall and trading levels, and would likely
provide the opportunity for a more relaxed timetable when it comes to assessing potential store closures. We believe the CVA would be the central requirement for Debenhams to be able to secure longer-term financing and would arguably be triggered if the business was unable to re-finance its current debt facilities. We also believe that the process would also be contingent on some form of equity fundraise.

red deb has to start being financially viable otherwise every rally will eventually get reversed.

Citi incoming.

wayneJ Does Li&Fung, by acting as an intermediary, effectively shield Debs from suppliers demanding cash upfront? What is happening to Debs credit insurance?
MassimoJ @1st - I'm 90% sure you can't write up goodwill, so if the goodwill was larger than expected I would imply that the assets being acquired have a lower fair value than initially thought and so goodwill needed to be higher to fill the gap...
hornblower DEBS had net debt of £286m in January and bonds and bank facility of £520m. To need £40m liquidity facility now cash outflow must have been massive. No more supplier credit?
11:46 am
BE11:46am

Li & Fung will help Debenhams reduce lead times, consolidate suppliers and increase quality in the supply chain. It is hard to quantify at this stage but main benefits are expected to be higher achieved gross margins (better full price sell through rather than higher bought in margins) and an improvement in working capital. Most importantly, in our view, it highlights that the company is still moving forwards in its operational strategy and the increased flexibility of a third party should allow volumes to be flexed more quickly than under the existing Debenhams sourcing model.

1st Lt. Fletcher Christian @Lemmy. Carillion paid £306m for Newcastle-based Eaga
BE11:46am

Sure, okay, but what about the debt?

BE11:47am

We would view this as the first step for Debenhams to reorganise its capital structure and that it provides the company more time to conclude the negotiations. The eventual outcome is uncertain but will likely involve one of the following options: 1) Debt for equity swap with lenders writing off a proportion of their debt; 2) A CVA agreement which will see both lease and debt liabilities reduced if there is an imminent threat of insolvency; or 3) An voluntary agreement with landlords to reduce the number of stores on an agreed timetable combined with a longer term refinancing. There is no announced timetable for this process but we note the new facility is only 12 months in duration and the interest rate steps up in calendar Q2 which provides an incentive to move quickly.

wayneJ @Massimo - I think there are some weird circumstances where effective u do write something up - eg buy Deb out of a CVA - and then decide the brand name is worth more than u paid for the entire co. (and only under some accounting standards)
wayneJ @Massimo - but generally your point holds
MassimoJ @WayneJ - yeah sure, you can write up some intangibles, but not the accounting goodwill line (I think)

BE11:55am

Here's Jefferies with the detail.

11:55 am
BE11:55am

1) EBITDA to be "not less than £340m" (cons: £333m, guidance: £335-345m); 2) Paid personal memberships declined 2% YOY (1H: -2%) to 3.21m with retention at 80% (1H: 81%). Members expected to be broadly flat in FY20 and grow in FY21; 3) Average income per personal member increased 3% (1H: 2%) due to a shift to more expensive monthly contracts; 4) Average income per B2B customer increased 5% (1H: +5%) to £21 with additional revenue under pay-for-use contracts and contract wins. 5) Insurance broking saw strong growth driven by never members and the underwriter, with motor policies +16% YOY (1H: +7%) and home +1.5% YOY (1H: -3%) although average income fell to £69 due to mix of new business with lower commissions. Capex expected to be broadly in line with guidance of £105m. FY19 results on 3 April

BE11:56am

And Barclays.

Pharma @red, that's true. No reason why car sharing should reduce the overall number of miles driven by much if anything (could increase it, depending on where they go between uses)
BE11:56am

There were several positives for the AA in FY19. The company reshaped its strategy, hit its targeted EBITDA figure, invested in improving its membership offering & insurance capabilities - delivering these within budget - renewed its key B2B contracts and saw its motor book grow by c16% yoy. However, a stabilisation & improvement in B2C membership is key and this is dependent on the retention rate improving, the area under most pressure. Management has new app-based products to entice members, but we don’t know what these are yet (more detail is promised at the FY results) and it is therefore difficult to assess whether they will transform the trajectory of the B2C business. The insurance strategy also requires an acceleration in EBITDA in a competitive market, which is unlikely to be visible within the financials until next year, in our view. The AA equity story continues to be about de-leveraging, in our view. The forecast trajectory of de-leverage is slow (FY19e 7.9x to 5.5x in FY23e) and although FY20 is likely to be a year of modest EBITDA growth, there is still uncertainty as to whether growth can accelerate in outer years, in our view.
